subjects.title: Indian Polity
subjects.description: Master Indian Constitution, Governance, and Political System

topics.title: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP)
topics.description: Part IV (Articles 36-51) - State's TO-DO list for Social & Economic Democracy

subTopics.title: DPSP ‚Äî Introduction & Complete Module
subTopics.description: Complete module covering origin, features, classification, and 150 questions

content.heading: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP)
content.body: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) ‚Äî Part IV (Articles 36‚Äì51). Think of DPSP as the constitution's TO-DO list for the State: positive, policy-guiding directives to establish social and economic democracy and a Welfare State. DPSP are fundamental in governance (Article 37) but are non-justiciable in courts. They were adopted into the Indian Constitution in 1950, having been influenced by Spain and Ireland (GOI Act 1935 called them 'Instrument of Instructions').
highlights: Article 37: Fundamental in governance but non-justiciable
Positive instructions to State (not negative like FR)

content.heading: Part IV ‚Äî Directive Principles of State Policy
content.body: DPSP form Part IV of the Indian Constitution, comprising Articles 36 to 51. These 16 articles (originally) were adopted on 26 January 1950 when the Constitution came into effect. Their primary role is to guide the State in policy formulation, lawmaking, and overall governance of the country.
highlights: Role: Guide State policy and lawmaking

content.heading: Origin Chain: SPAIN ‚Üí IRELAND ‚Üí INDIA
content.body: Spain was the first country to adopt directive principles in their constitution. Ireland later borrowed and adapted these concepts. Finally, India borrowed the concept from Ireland's constitution when framing our own Constitution. The Government of India Act 1935 used the term 'Instrument of Instructions' which directly influenced how DPSP were framed in the Indian Constitution.
highlights: Spain: First to adopt directive principles

content.heading: 11 Key Features of DPSP
content.body: DPSP have several distinctive characteristics that set them apart from Fundamental Rights. They are addressed to the State (not individuals), contain positive instructions (State must DO actions), and are non-justiciable in courts as per Article 37 (recommended by Tej Bahadur Sapru Committee). However, they are justiciable in the 'Court of the People' through elections and political accountability. DPSP promote social and economic democracy, reduce inequality, establish a Welfare State (Article 38), and encourage inclusive and sustainable growth. While fundamental in governance, they are not self-executory and require legislative implementation (e.g., MGNREGA, RTE Act). Article 40 served as the precursor to Panchayati Raj Institutions (73rd Amendment).
highlights: Fundamental in governance but not enforceable
Not self-executory (need laws like MGNREGA, RTE)

content.title: R-N-A-L-S ‚Äî Thinkers Who Commented on DPSP

breakdown.meaning: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called DPSP 'novel features' of the Constitution
Called DPSP 'the conscience of the Constitution'
Called DPSP 'life-giving provisions of the Constitution'
Criticized DPSP as 'a cheque payable at the convenience of the bank (State)'
Articles: 38, 39, 39A, 41, 42, 43, 43A, 47 ‚Äî Focus on social & economic justice, welfare state, equal distribution, workers' rights
Articles: 40, 43, 43B, 46, 47, 48 ‚Äî Focus on village panchayats, cottage industries, prohibition, cow protection, rural development
Articles: 44, 45, 48, 48A, 49, 50, 51 ‚Äî Focus on UCC, education, environment protection, monuments, separation of judiciary, international peace

content.heading: DPSP ‚Äî Complete Exam Summary
content.body: Part IV | Articles 36‚Äì51 | Origin: Spain ‚Üí Ireland ‚Üí India (S-I-I). Key features: Addressed to State, Positive instructions, Non-justiciable (Sapru Committee), Promote welfare state & social-economic democracy, Not self-executory, Precursor of PRIs. Classification: S-G-L (Socialist, Gandhian, Liberal-Intellectual). Thinkers: R-N-A-L-S (Rau-Novel-Austin-Life-Shah). Important articles: 37 (fundamental in governance), 38 (welfare state), 40 (PRIs), 44 (UCC), 48A (environment). Implementation: MGNREGA (Art 41), RTE Act (Art 45). Triple NON: Non-justiciable, Non-enforceable, Non-self-executory.
highlights: Thinkers: R-N-A-L-S (Rau, Novel, Austin, Life, Shah)

quiz.prompt: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are enshrined in which Part of the Indian Constitution?

quiz.reason: Spain was historically first to adopt similar guiding principles.

content.heading: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth
content.body: Article 15 is one of the key provisions ensuring equality. It prohibits the State from discriminating against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. However, the State may make special provisions for women, children, and socially and educationally backward classes.
highlights: No citizen shall be discriminated on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth
Special provisions allowed for women and children
Special provisions for advancement of SC/ST/OBC allowed (Article 15(4) and 15(5))

breakdown.meaning: Cannot discriminate based on religious beliefs
Cannot discriminate based on racial origin
Cannot discriminate based on caste affiliation

content.title: Constitutional Amendments to Article 15
points: 15(3) - Special provisions for women and children
15(4) - Added by 1st Amendment (1951) - Special provisions for SC/ST and backward classes
15(5) - Added by 93rd Amendment (2005) - Special provisions for admission in educational institutions
15(6) - Added by 103rd Amendment (2019) - Economically weaker sections (EWS) reservation
